<summary>
• The text discusses the transport properties of non-equilibrium dynamical systems, specifically ratchet systems with asymmetric periodic potentials.
• The interest in ratchet systems comes from potential applications in extracting work from unbiased noisy fluctuations, as seen in biological systems.
• Chaotic systems, which are sensitive to initial conditions and parameter values, exhibit complex phase space structures with co-existing attractors and stability islands.
• Mateos considered a specific ratchet model with a periodically forced underdamped particle and found that the ensemble average velocity could be positive or negative depending on the amplitude of the periodic forcing.
• He conjectured a connection between current reversals and bifurcations from chaotic to periodic behavior.
• Barbi and Salerno challenged this conjecture, showing that current reversals could occur in the absence of bifurcations.
• The authors investigate the current in the same system as considered by Mateos and Barbi and Salerno, focusing on the impact of different ensembles and the importance of discarding transients.
• The study finds that the current depends significantly on the details of the initial ensemble and that bifurcations for trajectory dynamics are associated with abrupt changes in the current, but not all bifurcations lead to current reversals.
</summary>

<summary>

* The text discusses the results of observations and simulations of six extrasolar planetary systems with highly eccentric planets.
* The observations were made using the Hobby-Eberly Telescope (HET) and other telescopes, and the data were analyzed to investigate the presence of additional planets.
* The simulations used Swift software to determine the regions in which additional planets could remain in stable orbits.
* The results showed that the short-period planets swept clean the region inside of about 0.5 au, while longer-period planets were affected by mean-motion resonances.
* The test particles oscillated in eccentricity with larger ranges for particles in resonance, and some systems had regions of instability at certain distances.
* The dynamical simulations complemented the detection limit determinations, and the three systems with the best limits had the lowest rms scatter about their orbital solutions.
* No evidence was found for additional planets in any of the six systems, but protected resonances were present and could be explored further with new high-precision HET data.
* The research was supported by grants from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Terrestrial Planet Finder Foundation Science Program.
* The Hobby-Eberly Telescope is a joint project of several universities and is named in honor of its principal benefactors, Willam P. Hobby and Robert E. Eberly.
</summary>

<summary>

* Supersymmetry (SUSY) is an extension of the Standard Model that solves the naturalness problem and predicts gauge coupling unification at the GUT scale.
* The no-scale type Khler potential is a popular choice for SUSY models, which predicts that all scalar masses and trilinear scalar couplings vanish when the cosmological constant is zero, leaving only gaugino masses as the source of supersymmetry breaking.
* The no-scale structure of the Khler potential is obtained in various models, including weakly coupled heterotic string theory and the sequestered sector scenario.
* In the minimal scenario, where universal gaugino masses are given at the GUT scale, the charged right-handed slepton is the lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP) if the d-term potential is negligible, but it is excluded by cosmological and LEP 2 bounds.
* In the case where universal gaugino masses are given above the GUT scale, the large group factor in the minimal SU(5) model makes slepton masses heavier, allowing for a larger parameter region and a viable LSP in the large parameter region.
* The charged stau LSP can also be avoided if gaugino masses at the GUT scale are non-universal, and the lsp can be wino-like, higgsino-like, or sneutrino depending on the masses of the hidden and observable sector fields.
* The minimal scenario is severely constrained by the minimal supersymmetric standard model (MSSM) Higgs mass bound and the LEP 2 bound, but the other two scenarios are not as severely constrained.
* The authors also discuss the possibility of discovering supersymmetric particles at the Tevatron run 2 or the LHC, and the importance of considering radiative corrections and the two-loop effects in the calculation of the Higgs mass and the slepton masses.
</summary>

• The ground state of the array has the spin configuration shown in the figure, with upspin and downspin states encoded as logic 1 and 0, respectively.

• However, the state with two spins aligned anti-parallel to the magnetic field (Fig. 1(b)) is a long-lived metastable state due to the weak magnetic field and the energy barrier between the two states.
• The metastable state can prevent decay to the global ground state (Fig. 1(a)) and cause a serious problem for logic signal propagation.
• In 1996, a more elegant solution was proposed to propagate the input state through a linear array by lowering two adjacent barriers pairwise at the same time, requiring a three-phase clock.
• The use of spin in classical irreversible logic gates dissipates a minimum amount of energy per bit flip, but the high power dissipation and difficulty in removing heat from the chip make it a challenge for practical applications.
• In 1996, a logically and physically reversible quantum inverter using two exchange coupled spins was proposed as a potential solution to overcome the Landauer barrier and reduce power dissipation.

<summary>
• Cataclysmic variables (CVs) are short-period binary systems with a white dwarf primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary.
• The secondary fills its Roche lobe and transfers mass to the white dwarf through the inner Lagrangian point.
• The orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors shows a lack of systems in the 2-3 hr period range (period gap) and a sharp cut-off at around 77 minutes.
• Theoretical models have not been able to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cut-off and the shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cut-off.
• Systems that evolve under the influence of gravitational radiation reach a minimum period at around 6 minutes, and the probability of finding a system within a given period range is proportional to the time taken to evolve through this region.
• The mass transfer rate and orbital period evolution reflect the radius evolution of the mass donor, which in turn is governed by two competing effects: mass transfer and thermal relaxation.
• The minimum period is affected by the assumed mass transfer rate and the assumed rate of orbital angular momentum (AM) losses. In this paper, the authors investigate ways to increase the period minimum by increasing the mass transfer rate and to "hide" the spike by introducing a spread of CV populations.
</summary>

<summary>
• The text discusses the observational evidence for the accelerated expansion of the universe and the role of dark energy (DE) in driving this expansion.
• Two approaches to describe DE and dark matter (DM) are introduced: fluids and scalar fields. Interactions within the dark sector are expected due to considerations like the holographic principle.
• The interaction between DE and DM affects the background dynamics, potentially solving the coincidence problem and satisfying the second law of thermodynamics.
• Observables such as the background evolution, emergence of large scale structure, and growth of matter density perturbations can be used to constrain the interaction between DE and DM, and current and future observational facilities offer prospects for detection or constraint.
</summary>

The text begins by discussing the observational evidence for the accelerated expansion of the universe, including the discovery of fainter-than-expected supernovae type Ia and various other observations such as temperature anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background, inhomogeneities in the matter distribution, the integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect, baryon acoustic oscillations, weak lensing, and gamma-ray bursts. The unknown nature of DE, which is driving the present epoch of accelerated expansion, has given rise to a great scientific effort to understand its properties.

Two possible approaches to describe DE and DM are introduced: fluids and scalar fields. Based on general considerations like the holographic principle, it is argued that the interaction within the dark sector is to be expected.

The interaction between DE and DM affects the overall evolution of the universe and its expansion history, the growth of matter and baryon density perturbations, the pattern of temperature anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background, and the evolution of the gravitational potential at late times. These observables are directly linked to the underlying theory of gravity, and the interaction could be constrained with observations of the background evolution and the emergence of large scale structure.

The text is organized as follows: the introduction describes the concordance model and its shortcomings, which motivates considering interactions within the dark sector. The subsequent sections discuss the theoretical developments of this field and the observational evidence that constrains the DM/DE interaction, as well as the prospects for detection or constraint with current and future observational facilities.

• Type 1 AGNs exhibit diverse broad and narrow emission lines, with broad lines arising in or near an accretion disk and narrow lines serving as reliable measures of the local quasar rest frame, except for "blue outliers" in sources with intermediate line widths.

• The text challenges the claim of a systematic redshift of FeII relative to [OIII]5007 in a majority of Type 1 quasars, suggesting that the observed shifts may be due to host galaxy contamination or blue outliers rather than a physical effect.

<summary>

* The solar corona is heated to 12 million kelvins while the visible surface is roughly 250 times cooler.
* Magnetic fields or waves are responsible for converting convective energy in the photosphere to thermal energy in the corona.
* The primary energy source for coronal heating lies in the convection zone below the solar photosphere, where 100 times more energy is available.
* Debate continues on whether the energy derives from dissipation of magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) waves or numerous small-scale magnetic reconnection events (nanoflares).
* Two types of magnetic disturbances in coronal structures are generated by the interaction of magnetic fields with convective flows: MHD waves and field-aligned currents.
* Wave propagation relies on plasma inertia, while field-aligned currents along coronal loops do not.
* Observations of high-frequency intensity oscillations of coronal structures have been made using the SECIS instrument in the Fe XIV green line.
* The SECIS instrument, installed at the Lomnicky Peak Observatory, will be used to search for high-frequency coronal oscillations.
</summary>

The text describes the heating of the solar corona, which is well known to be much hotter than the visible surface of the sun. The primary energy source for this heating is believed to be in the convection zone below the solar photosphere, where 100 times more energy is available. The debate continues on whether the energy derives from dissipation of magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) waves or numerous small-scale magnetic reconnection events (nanoflares). Two types of magnetic disturbances in coronal structures are generated by the interaction of magnetic fields with convective flows: MHD waves and field-aligned currents. Wave propagation relies on plasma inertia, while field-aligned currents along coronal loops do not. Observations of high-frequency intensity oscillations of coronal structures have been made using the SECIS instrument in the Fe XIV green line, and the SECIS instrument, installed at the Lomnicky Peak Observatory, will be used to search for high-frequency coronal oscillations.

<summary>
• Water vapor is an important molecule in interstellar and circumstellar clouds, but its role at large spatial scales has not been studied due to the lack of information from the 6@xmath8 - 5@xmath9 masing transition at 22 GHz.
• Other water lines, such as the 3@xmath11 - 2@xmath12 transition at 183 GHz, have been used to map water emission at large scales, revealing an abundance of 10@xmath7 in molecular clouds.
• The ISO satellite has provided thermal water lines in the middle and far-infrared, but its poor angular resolution prevents detailed studies of spatial structure and physical conditions.
• Ground-based observations of another masing transition of water vapor with similar properties to the 183 GHz line could aid in deriving water abundances and providing constraints on emitting regions.
• The 325 GHz line of water vapor was observed by Menten et al. in 1990, but no maps were obtained. Here, we report the detection of extended water emission at 325 GHz and an abundance of 10@xmath4 10@xmath5 in the plateau.
• Ground-based observations provide much finer spatial resolution and accurate estimates of water abundance, while also revealing differences in brightness temperatures between water lines.
• The observations were made with the 10.4 m telescope at the Caltech Submillimeter Observatory and yielded a line intensity ratio of 10 - 20 if both lines were observed with a telescope of the same beam size.
• The results highlight the importance of ground-based observations for understanding the behavior of water masers and the physical conditions of interstellar clouds.
</summary>

<summary>
• Threshold nets are obtained by assigning weights to nodes and connecting nodes with combined weights above a threshold.
• They can produce graphs with various degree distributions, including scale-free networks.
• Threshold nets have recently gained attention due to their modular structure and ease of computing structural measures.
• Hagberg et al. encode threshold graphs using a two-letter sequence representation.
• New nodes connect to none of the existing nodes of the same type and all of the nodes of the other type.
• Threshold graphs have a modular structure, with cliques formed by consecutive nodes of the same type.
• Fast algorithms exist to compute degree distribution, triangles, betweenness centrality, and eigenvalues of threshold nets.
• Sequence nets are a broader class of nets constructed from a sequence using deterministic rules of connectivity.
• Sequence nets retain the desirable properties of threshold nets, such as modularity and easily computable structural measures.
• The diameter of sequence nets grows linearly with the number of letters in the alphabet, making them comparable to many everyday life complex nets.
• The text explores two-letter and three-letter sequence nets, finding fifteen distinct rules with fewer than five connections and their complements.
• Some three-letter sequence nets can be mapped to generalized forms of threshold nets.
• The text raises open questions, such as finding sequences that lead to connected nets and mapping sequence nets to generalized threshold nets systematically.
• The text also discusses the possibility of applying connectivity rules only to the preceding letters instead of all preceding letters.
</summary>

• The authors find new effects due to strong electron-phonon coupling in both the one-band and two-band cases.
• For two-band superconductors, they examine the case of highly decoupled bands and look for signatures of the low energy scale, the effect of integration of the bands, and the response to inter- and intraband impurities.

• The study has implications for device applications and provides fundamental signatures of order parameter symmetry, such as those observed in d-wave superconductivity.

• The classification of time series data using a 1-nearest neighbor (1-nn) algorithm with dynamic time warping (DTW) distance is an important task in data mining.
• DTW distance is a shape-based similarity measure that uses a dynamic programming technique to find the minimum distance between two time series.
• Global constraints, such as Sakoe-Chiba band and Itakura parallelogram, are used to limit the permissible warping paths and improve the accuracy of DTW.
• Ratanamahatana-Keogh band (R-K band) is a recent representation of a global constraint that allows adjusting the constraint according to each class's warping path.
• The authors propose two learning algorithms, band boundary extraction and iterative learning, to select the best R-K band for time series classification.
• Silhouette index is used as a heuristic function to select the band that yields the best prediction accuracy.
• The authors use a cluster for their experiments and thank Chulalongkorn University for providing it.
• The proposed algorithm uses 1-nn classification with DTW distance and the selected R-K band as a global constraint, and a lower bound is used to speed up the computation.
</summary>

• Uniformization theorems give meromorphic functions with poles of orders and exponential singularities at punctures.
• Exponential singularities are singularities of functions or 1-forms that decay exponentially and converge along certain directions.
• Spaces of functions and 1-forms with exponential singularities depend only on their types.
• Exp-algebraic curves are a less rigid version of log-Riemann surfaces, consisting of a compact Riemann surface and equivalence classes of meromorphic functions with poles at punctures.
• Degree zero line bundles and meromorphic connections can be associated with exp-algebraic curves.
• Theorem states that two exp-algebraic curves with the same underlying Riemann surface, set of punctures, isomorphic line bundles, and isomorphic meromorphic sections have the same exp-algebraic structure.
• Functions with exponential singularities have applications in algebraic geometry, integration of integrable systems, and realization of divisors on compact Riemann surfaces.
</summary>

- Molecular hydrogen (H2) is the most abundant molecule in the universe and plays a crucial role in interstellar chemistry, with dust grains being the favored habitat for its formation.
- Hydrogen atoms (H) can stick weakly (physisorbed) or strongly (chemisorbed) to dust grain surfaces, and the sticking of H onto carbonaceous or silicate dust grains is important for H2 formation.
- In the interstellar medium (ISM), a significant portion of the available surface area for chemistry is in the form of very small grains or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).
- PAHs are predicted to have characteristics similar to graphite surfaces, and the first hydrogenation of neutral PAHs is associated with a barrier, but subsequent hydrogenations are barrierless.
- PAH cations, which are present at lower extinction levels and reside at the surfaces of photodissociation regions (PDRs), also play an important role in H2 formation.
- The hydrogenation of PAH cations is an efficient route to form H2, and recent experiments have shown that highly hydrogenated PAHs are efficient catalysts for H2 formation.
- The authors of this letter conducted an experiment to study the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase and observed that odd hydrogenation states predominantly populate the mass spectrum.
- The authors found that the further hydrogenation of PAH cations is associated with a barrier if the number of already attached hydrogen atoms is odd, and no barrier if this number is even. This alternating barrier-no barrier occurrence seems to remain with increasing hydrogenation.
</summary>

Additionally, the authors used a radiofrequency ion trap and time-of-flight mass spectrometry to study the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase. They found that the first hydrogenation of coronene cations is barrierless, but subsequent hydrogenations have barriers that decrease with increasing hydrogenation. The authors suggest that superhydrogenated PAH cations should also be found in the interstellar medium and be important catalysts for H2 formation. The research was supported by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO).

- The existence and thermal relic abundance of dark matter (DM) have been established by the WMAP experiment, and the weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP) is a promising candidate.
- A viable DM candidate beyond the Standard Model (SM) can be accommodated by introducing an inert scalar field with the inert property, ensuring the stability of the DM candidate.
- The Higgs Triplet Model (HTM) is a possible framework for accommodating the WIMP DM candidate, and it can explain tiny neutrino masses through the seesaw mechanism or the Higgs Triplet Model.
- The HTM introduces a triplet scalar field with large majorana masses for neutrinos, and the vev of this field breaks lepton number conservation at the trilinear term.
- The smallness of neutrino masses requires the mass of the triplet field to be much larger than the electroweak scale, and the neutrino mass matrix is given by that of the Yukawa matrix.
- The HTM predicts lepton flavor violation (LFV) decays of charged leptons at the tree and one-loop levels, and the relation between these decays and neutrino mass matrix is constrained by oscillation data.
- To explain the small neutrino masses with a detectable light doubly charged component of the triplet field, the $\\xmath14$ parameter has to be taken to be unnaturally much lower than the electroweak scale.
- The HTM can be extended to include a natural suppression mechanism for the $\\xmath14$ parameter, while also accommodating the DM candidate. In this extension, lepton number conservation is imposed to the Lagrangian to forbid the $\\xmath14$-term at the tree level, while the triplet yukawa term exists.
</summary>

Additionally, the text discusses the possibility of the majoron, a particle associated with the spontaneous breaking of lepton number conservation, evading experimental searches due to its weak interaction with matter fields. The text also mentions the potential collider signatures for probing the large mass scale of the triplet field in the HTM.

- The study of dipole moments of elementary particles, including electrons and muons, has led to significant advancements in subatomic physics, from the discovery of spin and radiative corrections to the development of QED and QCD.
- The magnetic moment of a charged particle with spin is given by the Dirac equation, and the anomaly arises from radiative corrections for point particles.
- The electron anomaly is now measured with a precision of about four parts in a billion, while the muon anomaly is measured to 0.5 parts per million and is sensitive to physics beyond the standard model at the Gev scale.
- The hadronic contribution to the muon anomaly cannot be calculated directly from QCD due to the low energy scale, but dispersion theory provides a relationship between the vacuum polarization loop and the cross section for a particular process.

- Susy contributions to the muon anomaly could be at a measurable level in a broad range of models and are complementary to the susy contributions to the magnetic and electric dipole moments for lepton-flavor violating processes.
- The muon magnetic and electric dipole moments can be represented as the real and imaginary parts of a generalized dipole operator, and the interaction Lagrangian becomes a function of the magnetic and electric fields and dipole moments.
- The muon anomaly measurement has placed serious restrictions on physics beyond the standard model, and the development of supersymmetric theories has increased interest in the experimental and theoretical value of the muon anomaly.
- A new experiment, E969, is proposed to further improve the experimental measurement of the muon anomaly with a goal of a total error of 0.1 ppm, while a letter of intent for an even more precise experiment was also submitted to J-PARC.

They also found that smaller systems equilibrate faster than larger ones, and that the length of the equilibration period plays a crucial role in building up or destroying correlations.

Additionally, the authors identified three different stages of relaxation during the equilibration of an interacting charged many-particle system: the velocity distribution approaches the Maxwellian distribution within a few plasma oscillation cycles, the configurational temperature relaxes at time scales about an order of magnitude longer, and the equilibration of long-range correlations is significantly slower and depends strongly on the system size. They concluded that increasing the system size alone in particle simulations can be insufficient and may result in misleading conclusions. In earlier numerical studies, no simulation time was specified before the actual measurement, and the quality of the equilibrium was not characterized, leading to the suspicion that many studies may have gotten stuck in the metastable hexatic phase instead of settling in the true equilibrium configuration due to the increasing computational resources in the first decade of the 21st century.

* The text discusses a stochastic formulation of quantum dissipation that extends beyond standard bosonic bath models to include non-interacting bosons, fermions, and spins. The stochastic Liouville equation (SLE) is used to prescribe quantum dissipative dynamics when bath effects are modeled as colored noises.
* The text also introduces the generalized hierarchical equations (GHE) as a family of deterministic simulation methods to solve the SLE by formally averaging out the noise variables. The GHE are derived for bosonic baths using spectral expansion and for non-gaussian and fermionic bath models using an alternative approach. The paper also discusses the application of the GHE to spin bath models using a dual-fermion representation.

<summary>

- The glass transition from a liquid to an amorphous solid is a largely unresolved problem in statistical physics.
- The glass transition is associated with a sharp increase in relaxation times and a departure from equilibrium at the experimental level.
- At the theoretical level, it is proposed that the glass transition is triggered by an underlying thermodynamic transition at the Kauzmann temperature.
- The Gibbs and DiMarzio argument is one of the first to propose an ideal glass transition at the Kauzmann temperature, where only one minimum-energy basin of attraction is accessible to the system.
- Recent studies using replica methods have provided evidence for such a transition in Lennard-Jones glass formers.
- However, experimental data and simulations of polydisperse hard-core disks have failed to detect any evidence of a thermodynamic transition up to extremely high packing fractions.
- The discrepancies between the reported simulated behavior of hard-disk and soft-sphere systems are under debate, with some attributing the differences to fundamental model differences and others to inappropriate sampling at low temperatures and high densities.
- The mode coupling theory (MCT) predicts a transition from a high-temperature liquid state to a low-temperature arrested state at a critical temperature Tc.
- The MCT equations of motion for correlation functions can be derived under general assumptions within the Lanczos recursion scheme or the Mori-Zwanzig formalism.

</summary>

Additionally, the text discusses a molecular dynamics simulation model adapted to the glass-forming NiZr system, which is used to determine the critical temperature Tc from evaluating and analyzing the nonergodicity parameter, the α-parameter in the ergodic regime, and the diffusion coefficients. The results show that the system exhibits a structural relaxation in three successive steps as predicted by the idealized schematic MCT, with a fast initial decay on the time scale of atomic vibrations, a β-relaxation regime, and a γ-relaxation. The nonergodicity parameters are defined as the non-vanishing asymptotic solution of the MCT equation, and their estimation from the coherent and incoherent scattering functions of Ni and Zr at t = 1005 K is presented. The memory functions are evaluated from the MD data for various temperatures

<summary>
• The text discusses a study on longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts in the context of a dyadic breast cancer study.
• Dyadic data are common in psychosocial and behavioral studies, and many social phenomena, such as dating and marital relationships, are interpersonal by definition.
• Interdependence in relationships leads to correlated observations, and understanding the interdependence of individuals within dyads is a primary objective of relationship research.
• Longitudinal dyadic data bring complications, including within-dyad correlation and the nonignorable dropout problem, which can lead to biased estimates if not accounted for.
• The text proposes a fully Bayesian approach to deal with longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts using a selection model.
• The approach models each subject's longitudinal measurement process using a transition model and accounts for the correlation within dyads using random effects.
• The discrete time survival model is used to link the dropout process with the longitudinal measurement process, and the data augmentation method is used to address the complex missing data problem.
</summary>

• The study focuses on a single-arm dyadic study of physiological and psychosocial aspects of pain among patients with breast cancer and their spouses.
• Spouses are the primary sources of support for individuals with breast cancer, and their support is associated with lower emotional distress and depressive symptoms in patients.
• The study aims to characterize the depression experience due to metastatic breast cancer from both patients and spouses' perspectives and examine the dyadic interaction and interdependence of patients and spouses over time.
• The results will be used to guide the design of an efficient prevention program to decrease depression among patients.
• The data were collected from 191 couples at three time points using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CESD) questionnaires, but a substantial number of dropouts occurred.
• The missingness of the CESD measurements is likely related to the current depression levels of the patients or spouses, so an nonignorable missing data mechanism is assumed.
• The proposed method, which accounts for nonignorable dropouts using a selection model, outperformed the complete-case and available-case analyses in a simulation study, yielding estimates with smaller bias

<summary>

- According to quantum electrodynamics, electric and magnetic field fluctuations give rise to a zero-point energy that never vanishes, even in the absence of electromagnetic sources.
- In 1948, Casimir predicted that two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum, assumed to be perfect conductors, should attract each other with a force inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation.
- Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized Casimir's theory to isotropic dielectrics, deriving the force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions using an analytical formula.
- The Casimir-Lifshitz force between isotropic dielectrics has been verified in several high-precision experiments, and the theory is receiving considerable attention in the modern literature.
- The theory has also been extended to anisotropic materials, predicting a torque between two parallel birefringent slabs that causes them to spontaneously rotate towards the configuration of minimum energy.
- The torque between two birefringent plates made of uniaxial materials immersed in a medium with dielectric function ε is given by equation [eqtorque], which depends on the dielectric functions of the plates and the medium at imaginary angular frequencies.
- The retarded van der Waals force between two birefringent plates is repulsive when they are immersed in liquid ethanol, making it possible to demonstrate the rotation of a disk placed on top of the plate in a reasonably straightforward experiment.
- The force between the disk and the plate was calculated using equation [eqforce], and the results showed that the equilibrium separation is about 100 nm, which can be tailored to the experimental needs by changing the thickness of the disk.
- The expected torque between the disk and the plate in liquid ethanol as a function of angle and distance was calculated and verified to vary as 1/r^2 and have maximum magnitude at r = 1 and z = 112, with opposite signs for quartz and calcite disks.
</summary>

• The text discusses a new framework for studying topologically biased random walks on graphs, which can be used for community detection and synchronization in complex networks. This approach allows for more efficient exploration of network structure using topological properties as biases.
• The study introduces mathematical tools for investigating bias parameters and uncovers details in the spectra of graph transition matrices, leading to a novel methodology for efficient community finding. The results hold for various biases, including those connected to graph properties and those not directly related.

<summary>
• The text discusses the threat of active p2p worms in unstructured peer-to-peer (p2p) overlay networks and proposes a holistic immunity system to provide both internal defense and external protection against these worms.
• The system uses a set of p2p hosts, called phagocytes, which are elected based on certain metrics and perform functions of defense and protection against active p2p worms.
• Phagocytes monitor managed p2p hosts' connection patterns and traffic volume to detect active p2p worm attacks and invoke local isolation, alert propagation, and software patching strategies.
• The system also provides access control and filtering mechanisms to prevent p2p traffic from leaking to external hosts and employs an adaptive and interaction-based computational puzzle scheme to prevent external attacks.
• The prototype system was evaluated on a massive-scale testbed, and the results validate its effectiveness and efficiency in defending against active p2p worms.
</summary>

Additionally:
• Active p2p worms utilize the p2p overlay to accurately find vulnerable hosts and infect them, making them more deadly than scanning worms.
• The phagocytes are those p2p hosts with the latest patches and can help their managed p2p hosts detect active p2p worms by monitoring their connection transactions and traffic volume.
• The detection mechanism is not a substitute for existing worm detection mechanisms but rather a complement to them, and it can defend against tricky p2p worms and external attacks.
• The system utilizes local isolation to limit the impact of active p2p worms as quickly as possible and propagates worm alerts to neighboring phagocytes to improve robustness against malicious alert propagation.
• The system can be deployed into both unstructured and structured p2p overlay networks, and it provides containment of p2p worms in the p2p overlay networks and filters p2p traffic to prevent external attacks.

<summary>
• Debris disks provide a look at an intermediate stage of stellar system evolution, representing the transition between the early formation of stars and planets and the mature stage of a system like our solar system.
• The observed infrared luminosity of circumstellar dust in debris disks is typically several orders of magnitude larger than estimated for the Kuiper and asteroid belts in our solar system.
• Two absorption components are detected toward hd32297, while only one is detected toward its proximate neighbors. The extra absorption component is likely caused by circumstellar material.
• The ism absorption is similar among hd32297 and its two closest neighbors and is likely due to absorption from the shell that defines the boundary of the local bubble. Some variation in local bubble absorption is detected toward 18 ori.
• Radial velocities of hd32297, bd+07 777s, and bd+07 778 are measured and differ significantly, indicating that they are likely not physically associated.
• Some indication of temporal variability is detected over several epochs of observations, but instrumental resolution variations and masking by the strong ism absorption make a definitive detection of circumstellar variability difficult.
• The measured circumstellar feature toward hd32297 is the strongest such absorption measured toward any nearby main sequence debris disk, 45 times greater than the column density of the prototypical edge-on debris disk, β Pic.
• An upper limit to the gas mass in the circumstellar disk surrounding hd32297 is estimated, assuming similar morphology and abundances as the stable gas around β Pic. Future observations are planned to determine the ratio of stable to variable gas and measure the gas disk absorption to independently measure the gas mass.

• The text describes an embedding scheme for solving the Dirac equation within a limited region of a larger system, where the rest of the system is replaced by an additional term added to the Hamiltonian for the limited region. The scheme is based on a trial function with continuity in the small component imposed variationally, and the problem of variational collapse is avoided by using a basis satisfying kinetic balance.
• The method is demonstrated to be stable and convergent through calculations of the spectrum of a confined hydrogen atom and the local density of states for a silver monolayer in an Au(001)/Ag/Au sandwich structure. The green function for the embedded Hamiltonian is also derived and illustrated in the continuum regime. Future applications are expected to be to defects and surfaces of materials containing heavier elements within the framework of density functional theory.

The authors consider the probability distribution of DNS formation at different redshifts, the duration of the inspiral phase, and the coalescence timescale.
- The authors find that about 96% of DNS coalescences occur above a critical redshift, contributing to the production of a continuous GW background. They also identify sources in the redshift interval responsible for a cosmic "popcorn" noise. The gravitational fluence produced by a DNS coalescence is calculated and the spectral properties of the stochastic background are characterized by the dimensionless parameter @xmath83.
- The authors compare their results with previous studies and discuss the detection possibility with laser beam interferometers. They find that the contribution of DNS coalescences to the gravitational background is out of reach of the first and second generation of interferometers but could be detected by future third-generation detectors like the Large Scale Cryogenic Gravitational Wave Telescope (LCGT) and the European Antenna EGO. They also discuss the optimal detection strategy using cross-correlation of the output of two detectors.

<summary>
• Shock acceleration of cosmic rays is a complex phenomenon with important nonlinear effects, including the backreaction of accelerated particles on the shock.
• Three approaches to account for this backreaction exist: numerical simulations, fluid models, and analytical methods.
• The fluid models treat cosmic rays as a relativistic second fluid and allow for the thermodynamics of modified shocks to be obtained, but do not provide information about the spectrum of accelerated particles.
• Analytical methods can help understand the physics of nonlinear effects, but have limitations due to the intrinsic complexity of the problem.
• A recent study investigated the effects of nonlinear backreaction on the maximum achievable energy and geometry of shock acceleration.
• A practical solution for the nonlinear regime is needed, and recent promising analytical solutions have appeared in the literature.
• Numerical simulations have shown that even a small fraction of particles injected from the thermal gas can significantly affect the shock, making the test particle approach unsuitable.
• The most visible effect of the backreaction on the shock is the flattening of the spectrum of accelerated particles at high energies.
• The analytical approaches reproduce the basic features of nonlinear shock acceleration, but there is no description of how nonlinear effects appear when a shock propagates in a medium with pre-existing accelerated particles.
• The linear theory of shock acceleration was developed in the 1970s but has never been generalized to its nonlinear extension.
• The backreaction can severely affect the process of re-energization of pre-accelerated particles, potentially leading to equipartition between cosmic rays and the gas.
• The authors present the first analytical treatment of shock acceleration in the presence of seed nonthermal particles and their nonlinear backreaction on the shock.
• The authors generalize a previous analytical method to describe nonlinear shock acceleration with monochromatic injection of quasi-thermal particles and present a calculation that accounts for both thermal particles and seed nonthermal particles.
• The case of supernova shocks propagating through the interstellar medium, where pressure balance exists between gas and cosmic rays, may be of interest.
• Nonlinear effects in shock acceleration of thermal particles result in the appearance of multiple solutions in certain regions of the parameter space

- The text describes a bidirectional relay network where users exchange information via a relay node using various protocols.

- TDBC combines the relay-to-user 1 and relay-to-user 2 phases into one broadcast phase, while MABC combines the user-to-relay and user-to-relay phases into one multiple-access phase.
- The goal is to utilize all available degrees of freedom of the three-node half-duplex bidirectional relay network with fading using adaptive mode selection and power allocation.
- The text discusses the achievable rates for six possible transmission modes and the conditions for maximum average sum rate.
- The text also mentions the importance of adaptive link selection and power control for rate maximization.
- The proposed protocol achieves the maximum sum rate in the considered bidirectional network and outperforms existing protocols based on simulation results.
- The advantages of buffering come at the expense of increased end-to-end delay, but this delay can be bounded to cause only a small loss in the achieved rate.
- The delay analysis of the proposed protocol is beyond the scope of the current work and is left for future research.

<summary>
• The acoustic oscillations in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) have a standard ruler scale that can be accurately calculated based on CMB measurements.
• This standard ruler can be used to measure the matter and energy content of the universe at low redshifts, but misinterpretations could occur if the CMB measurements are misled by new physics.
• The interpretation of low-redshift acoustic oscillations is robust if the CMB correctly tells us the baryon-to-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality.
• The sound horizon, which is the comoving distance that a sound wave can travel between the end of inflation and the epoch of recombination, depends only on the baryon-to-photon ratio and the redshift of equality.
• The baryon-to-photon ratio is exquisitely well measured in the CMB power spectrum, allowing for precise measurements of the sound horizon and the wavelength of baryonic features in the mass power spectrum.
• Other cosmological measurements, such as galaxy surveys and weak lensing surveys, can be used to measure the actual densities and thereby constrain the presence of unknown relativistic species.
• The acoustic oscillation standard ruler method depends only on the redshift of equality, but other cosmological measurements are well-poised to measure the actual densities and provide additional constraints on the cosmology.
</summary>

<summary>
• The text discusses the proposal of an ansatz for the neutrino mass matrix in the context of neutrino oscillations and their potential connection to a deeper theory beyond the Standard Model.
• The ansatz, motivated by an SO(10) grand unified model, suggests that the neutrino mass matrix is real and symmetric, leading to specific predictions for neutrino masses and mixing angles.
• The authors investigate the consequences of this ansatz by combining it with experimental information on neutrino oscillations and discuss its implications for the texture of the neutrino mass matrix.
• They also consider the possibility of complex neutrino mass matrices and their relation to the physical neutrino masses and mixing matrix.
• The authors note that the determination of neutrino masses and the underlying neutrino mass matrix is an ongoing research topic, and the results presented here are subject to future improvements and refinements.
</summary>

<summary>

- The contact pattern among individuals and their age groups can be modeled using contact matrices or continuous functions in deterministic models, but network analysis methods provide a more precise investigation of contact structures and their impact on disease spread.
- Scale-free networks, which have a power-law degree distribution, are common in many real-world networks, including human sexual contacts and animal movements. These networks have high heterogeneity, with many vertices having a low number of contacts and a few vertices having a high number of contacts.
- The Barabasi-Albert (BA) algorithm was used to generate scale-free networks, and their structural properties were compared to those generated by other methods (MA, MB, MR, and Kalisky algorithms). BA networks are more centralized and efficient than other networks, while MB networks are decentralized and less efficient.
- The spread of diseases in scale-free networks was simulated using susceptible-infected (SI) and susceptible-infected-susceptible (SIS) models. The results showed that the prevalence of diseases tends to stabilize in the same level despite the addition of vertices and an increase in the number of edges. However, the equilibrium level of prevalence varies significantly among networks with the same degree distribution.
- Undirected networks showed that the disease spreads independently of the probability of infection and tends to stabilize in the same level despite the addition of vertices. The prevalence increases with an increase in the number of edges. BA networks have the lowest prevalence in spreading simulations.
- Directed networks showed that the disease spreads independently of the probability of infection and tends to stabilize in the same level despite the addition of vertices. The prevalence increases with an increase in the number of edges. Kalisky networks have a slightly higher equilibrium prevalence than other networks.
- The results of the simulations demonstrate that the topological features of a network can influence the dynamics on the network, and the increase in the number of edges may promote the spread of diseases. The prevention of potentially infectious contacts can contribute to controlling a disease in cases of sanitary emergencies.
</summary>

• GRBs are believed to be of cosmological origin based on the detection of X-ray, optical, and radio afterglows.
• The fireball model is favored, but the degree of beaming is still uncertain, making it difficult to determine the energetics involved.
• Three methods have been proposed to determine the degree of beaming in GRBs: optical light curve breaks, polarization, and orphan afterglows.
• The first method, based on optical light curve breaks, is not conclusive due to the smoothness of the breaks and the presence of other factors that can cause light curve breaks.
• The second method, based on polarization, is difficult to observe under certain conditions and has only been reported in a few cases.
• The third method, based on orphan afterglows, is promising but faces challenges in distinguishing between orphan afterglows from failed GRBs (fGRBs) and jetted GRBs.
• fGRBs are fireballs with lower Lorentz factors than successful GRBs but still much greater than unity. They can produce orphan afterglows and are associated with prominent afterglows.

</summary>

Additionally, the text discusses the concept of fGRBs and the difficulties in distinguishing between fGRB orphans and jetted GRB orphans. It suggests possible solutions, such as improving the detection limit, observing the rising phase of the orphan, using radio observations, and detecting gravitational wave or neutrino radiation associated with GRBs. The text also mentions that strange star progenitor models may result in fewer fGRBs due to the absence of baryon contamination.

• Cosmic bursts of gamma rays, such as GRB 011211 and GRB 001025, are elusive events that last less than a minute and produce x-ray afterglows which can be detected for several hours or days.
• GRB 011211, detected by BEPPOSAX on December 11, 2001, was the longest event localized with BEPPOSAX and had a long duration and faintness in x-rays. An optical afterglow was identified and its redshift was measured to be z=2.14.
• GRB 001025, detected by RXTE on October 25, 2000, had a shorter duration and a higher peak flux in x-rays. No optical afterglow was detected, and it is considered unlikely that the x-ray source is an AGN.
• The x-ray spectra of both GRB afterglows can be fit with a simple power-law model, and no significant absorption above the galactic value was detected. The lack of absorption is consistent with the lack of reddening in the optical afterglow of GRB 011211.
</summary>

The text discusses a 2D extension of the random dimer model (2D-drdm) for analyzing the localization properties of a correlated disorder potential in a 2D square lattice. In the non-interacting regime, the 2D-drdm model introduces delocalized states if the resonance energy characterizing these structures is present in the unperturbed system's spectrum. With weak interactions, the density spatial fluctuations are driven, and a mode-matching argument reveals that the resonance energy is responsible for these phenomena. This results in a non-monotonic behavior of the condensate fraction as a function of the disorder strength and its enhancement for values close to the resonance condition. The findings suggest that short-range correlations in a disordered potential can modify and enhance the coherence of a many-body system in the weak interacting regime. These effects could be measured in ultracold atoms using accurate density and coherence measurements, such as fringes contrast interference experiments. The results could also be extended to homogeneous systems with engineered impurities that are transparent for a given energy.

• The authors prove Behsaz-Hatami-Mahmoodian's conjecture for some cases using their bounds.
• The text also discusses an algorithm to find the maximum independent set in graphs with bounded treewidth, which is used to solve the problem for generalized petersen graphs with a fixed number of vertices in the outer cycle.

<summary>
• MDIQKD is a quantum key distribution protocol where neither Alice nor Bob perform any measurement, but they only send out quantum signals to a measurement unit (Mu).
• Mu is a willing participant of the protocol and can be an untrusted and completely controlled by the eavesdropper (Eve).
• MDIQKD is based on a reversed EPR-based QKD protocol and is remarkable for removing all potential loopholes of the detectors without sacrificing the performance of standard QKD.
• The basic idea of MDIQKD is to establish a quantum correlation between Alice and Bob through Mu, and then proceed with standard post-processing steps such as error rate estimation, error correction, and privacy amplification.
• MDIQKD with infinite number of decoy states and polarization encoding can cover about twice the distance of standard decoyed QKD.
• The only assumption needed in MDIQKD is that the preparation of the quantum signal sources by Alice and Bob is almost perfect and carefully characterized.
• One of the main imperfections of the sources is the basis-dependent flaw, which decreases the achievable distance in standard BB84.
• The security of MDIQKD under the imperfection of the basis-dependent flaw needs to be investigated.
• Two schemes of phase encoding MDIQKD have been proposed, and their security has been proven with basis-dependent flaw.
• The first scheme employs phase locking of two separate laser sources, while the second one uses the conversion of phase encoding into polarization encoding.
</summary>

- The first evidence of time reversal symmetry violation in the kaon system has been found, but no other signals of violation have been detected.
- Studying time reversal symmetry is crucial for understanding physics beyond the Standard Model.
- Alternatives to the Standard Model, such as dynamical symmetry breaking, multi-Higgs models, spontaneous symmetry breaking, grand unified theories, extended gauge groups, and supersymmetric theories, all imply specific ways of time reversal symmetry violation.
- Hadronic degrees of freedom are useful for analyzing nuclear physics tests of time reversal symmetry due to the moderate energies involved.
- Effective one boson exchange potentials can be used to treat nuclear structure and extract effective hadronic coupling constants.
- To compare upper bounds on a more fundamental level, it's necessary to relate hadronic degrees of freedom to quark degrees of freedom.
- The constituent quark model has been successful in describing low energy phenomena and can be used to relate quark operators to effective hadronic operators.
- The Virginia potential assumes a quark pairing mechanism to generate effective meson-nucleon coupling constants and can be used to evaluate matrix elements and arrive at relations between quark and hadronic coupling strengths.
</summary>

• Quantum entanglement is a physical resource in quantum mechanics, characterized by conservation laws and manipulated independently of physical realization. It is useful for making quantitative predictions and quantifying entanglement.
• The entropy of entanglement is a measure of entanglement for pure bipartite systems, but for mixed states, the quantification becomes less clear due to the inherent uncertainty of the mixed state description.
• The entanglement of formation and entanglement of distillation are measures that circumvent the problem of quantifying entanglement in mixed states by evaluating lower and upper bounds, respectively.
• The text discusses the dynamics of entanglement in a cascaded qubit system, which produces unconditional entangled states as the steady-state solution to a master equation. The authors analyze the conditional evolution of the qubit system to understand the dynamical creation of entanglement and the infinitely slow approach to steady state in the special case. They demonstrate that the conditional dynamics exhibit a distinct bimodality, where the approach to the bell state is only one of two possibilities for the asymptotic evolution: an entangled-state cycle, where the qubits execute a sustained stochastic switching between two bell states.
</summary>

<summary>
• The text discusses the differences in infrared emission between Type 1 and Type 2 Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), attributing the observed anisotropy to angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration by a dust torus.
• The dust torus is optically and geometrically thick, extending from sub-parsec to several tens of parsecs, and absorbs incident UV/optical radiation, re-emitting it in the infrared.
• Observations show that Type 1 AGN exhibit stronger infrared emission than Type 2 AGN for the same intrinsic luminosity, due to the face-on view of the torus in Type 1 AGN exposing the innermost hot dust to the observer.
• The analysis uses a nearly isotropically selected and complete sample of quasars and radio galaxies with hidden quasars to quantify the wavelength dependence of the anisotropy in the infrared.
• The study improves the analysis by using host-galaxy subtraction for radio galaxies and clumpy torus models for interpretation.
• The results show that the average sed of Type 1 AGN has a higher infrared emission than Type 2 AGN, with the discrepancy being largest in the near-infrared and flattening out towards longer wavelengths.
• The authors test if a single absorber and emitter (the dust torus) may be responsible for the radio galaxy/quasar anisotropy and find that a clumpy torus model fits the data well, reproducing the observed anisotropy reasonably over most of the wavelength range.
</summary>

<summary>
• Continuous variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) between Alice and Bob has seen improvements in theory and experiment, but security loopholes remain due to the neglected local oscillator (LO) intensity.
• Eve can exploit LO intensity fluctuations to reduce channel excess noise and intercept partial or full secret keys without being detected if Bob does not scale his measurements with instantaneous LO intensity values.
• Reverse reconciliation is more sensitive to LO intensity attacks than direct reconciliation, and even a small LO intensity fluctuation can compromise the secret key rate for long-distance communication.
• Eve can hide her attack by reducing the LO intensity and increase channel excess noise for some signal pulses while decreasing it for others, making the overall estimated excess noise lower than the real one.
• The analysis shows that monitoring LO intensity and scaling measurements with instantaneous intensity values is crucial for secure CVQKD implementation.
• The paper also discusses the calculation of the holevo bound for direct and reverse reconciliation using Weedbrook's entangling cloner model and the secret key rates shared by Alice and Bob under LO intensity attacks.
• The work is supported by various grants and acknowledges support from NUDT under grant no. kxk130201.
</summary>

• Leo i is a unique dwarf spheroidal (dsph) galaxy in the Local Group, with a young stellar population and a larger fraction of intermediate-age and young stars compared to other dsphs. It lacks a conspicuous old population and has a wide range of ages, from at least 10.15 Gyr to less than 1 Gyr. The star formation seems to have proceeded continuously, without distinct bursts, throughout the galaxy's history.
• The analysis of the new HST data and the stellar populations of Leo i reveals that the galaxy's broad main sequence turnoff/subgiant region and wide range in luminosity of the red clump indicate that star formation extended from at least 10.15 Gyr ago to less than 1 Gyr ago. The lack of a prominent horizontal branch suggests that the fraction of stars older than 10 Gyr is small, and the beginning of significant star formation may have been delayed in Leo i compared to other dsphs. The presence of bright, yellow stars in the same area of the color-magnitude diagram as anomalous cepheids suggests that some of these stars may be classical cepheids in the lower extreme of mass, luminosity, and period. Important questions about Leo i remain, including the existence of a very old stellar population, variations of the star formation across the galaxy, and the presence or absence of a horizontal branch in the outer parts of Leo i. Further observations are needed to address these questions and understand the formation and evolution of Leo i, as well as its implications for general questions about galaxy formation and the evolution of galaxies of different morphological types.

- The text discusses a result from Berestycki et al. (2010) regarding the principal eigenvalue of the Laplacian perturbed by a divergence-free drift in dimensions 10 and higher. The result asserts that the principal eigenvalue remains bounded as the drift strength increases if and only if there exists a first integral of the flow that satisfies certain conditions. Intuitively, this means that functions satisfying these conditions are constant along the flow of the vector field, and the existence of non-trivial first integrals allows for flow lines that remain within the domain.
- The authors aim to extend this result to the fractional Laplacian in place of the classical Laplacian. They define the set of nonzero first integrals in the Sobolev space equipped with the norm coming from the Dirichlet form of the fractional Laplacian. The main difficulty lies in the roughness and non-locality of the fractional Laplacian, which prevent a direct application of differential calculus. The authors use conditioning, approximation techniques, and properties of the Green function and heat kernel of gradient perturbations to define and study the principal eigenpair for the fractional Laplacian.
</summary>

<summary>
• Z Andromedae (Z And) is a symbiotic system consisting of a white dwarf (WD), a red giant (RG), and circumstellar and circumbinary nebulae.
• The system exhibits nonuniform eruptions, with the most notable being the 1984-1986 event, which had two maxima in its visual magnitude profile.
• The 1984-1986 event was characterized by the ejection of shells during each outburst, with the first one causing the formation of silicate grains and the second one revealing the presence of a relatively strong shock.

• The physical conditions in the nebulae were modeled using the wind collision model, revealing unexpected profiles of physical conditions.
• The collision of the WD wind with a shell ejected from the RG led to the formation of high-density fragments that prevented the black body flux from reaching the nebula, reducing the ionization parameter.
• The calculated siiii]/niv ] line ratios were better reproduced by adopting lower than solar relative abundances of silicon for certain models.
• The observed continuum spectral energy distribution (SED) was compared with model calculations, revealing strong self-absorption of free-free radiation from the nebulae for frequencies below 1010 Hz.
</summary>

Additionally:
• The 1984-1986 outburst was remarkable for its double-peaked structure and low brightness.
• The minimum between the two peaks was accompanied by a dip in the ionization parameter, which was constrained by the detailed modeling of the uv line spectra.
• The sharp drop in the ionization parameter was due to the sudden increase in the distance between the WD and the downstream nebula reached by the WD black body flux.
• The grains did not have enough time to develop due to the recent formation of the shell at the time of observations.
• The small peaks in the light curve before and after the 1984-1986 burst were most probably due to RG shell ejections.
• Broad lines and collimated jets were observed during other symbiotic systems, but not during the 1984-1986 outburst of Z And.

• The lack of frequency and electric field dependent conductivity investigation for systematic variation of network densities and correlation study between the onset frequency and length scale determined from nonlinear transport is addressed in this paper.

• Grover's algorithm is a quantum algorithm that can search an unsorted database more efficiently than classical algorithms. It was shown by Grover that search can be carried out with only a quadratic number of steps, compared to the linear number of steps required in classical computation.
• The three-qubit version of Grover's algorithm is more complex than the two-qubit version, but it can be implemented using four-level squids in cavity-QED. The scheme is based on resonant and off-resonant interaction of the cavity field with the squid transitions and application of resonant microwave pulses.
• The implementation of three-qubit Grover search using four-level squids in cavity-QED has several advantages over the conventional gate decomposition method. It reduces the number of steps required, simplifies the implementation, and reduces the probability of error.

- In the 1970s, many-body theory attracted attention for its effects on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra, particularly in metals where conduction band electrons can have significant impacts on core level peaks.
- The excitation process in XPS is not adiabatic, leading to shake-up effects in the form of single-particle and collective excitations.
- Shake-up effects result in plasmon replicas in the spectrum, with the main peak at the adiabatic position and replicas shifted to lower kinetic energy by the plasma frequency.
- For pristine graphene, the chemical potential is not inside an energy band or a band gap, but it still exhibits a low-energy tailing.
- The 2D character of graphene results in 2D plasmons with different dispersion, making it challenging to interpret XPS spectra using Doniach-Sunji fitting.
- The text provides a detailed derivation of core-level spectra for 2D systems and presents numerical results for pristine and doped free-standing graphene.
- The agreement between theoretical results and experimental spectra is quite good, and the work introduces a convenient way to include gaussian instrumental broadening in the formalism.
</summary>

- The phase-field method is a popular simulation technique for studying microstructure formation during solidification due to its algorithmic simplicity.
- The method describes the geometry in terms of phase fields, which obey simple partial differential equations that can be easily coded using standard numerical methods.
- The text discusses several topics where robust phase-field modelling tools are not yet available, including the thin-interface limit of two-sided models, orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification, and the inclusion of microscopic fluctuations in phase-field equations.
- The thin-interface limit of two-sided phase-field models cannot eliminate all effects linked to the finite interface thickness.
- The standard equation of motion for the orientation field is not appropriate for the evolution of coherent crystalline matter.
- The standard approach for including microscopic fluctuations in phase-field equations cannot be used to investigate the process of nucleation.
- The precision and performance of phase-field models have been greatly enhanced in the last decade by a detailed control of their properties.
- The phase-field method is rooted in the mean-field description of spatially diffuse interfaces by order parameters, but needs to bridge the scale gap between the thickness of physical solid-liquid interfaces and the typical scale of microstructures.
- The text highlights the challenges and limitations of the phase-field method and outlines potential future directions for research.
</summary>

• The fundamental atmospheric parameters of stars, including effective temperature, surface gravity, mass, age, and metallicity, are crucial for chemo-dynamical studies of the Milky Way and other galaxies.
• Spectroscopic surveys like SEGUE, RAVE, GAIA-ESO, and Hermes enable accurate determination of these parameters through spectroscopic methods.
• Effective temperature, surface gravity, and metallicity can be estimated from a spectrum using the information from Fe and Fe absorption lines under the assumption of hydrostatic equilibrium (HE) and local thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE).
• However, observational and theoretical evidence suggests that systematic biases exist due to the breakdown of the LTE assumption, particularly in low-metallicity and/or low-surface gravity stars.

- The kinetics of DNA loop formation in semiflexible polymers under static and fluctuating tension have been studied using simulations and experiments.
- Semiflexible polymers are modeled as chains of beads with stretching and bending energy interactions.
- The looping time, defined as the mean first-passage time to cross the free energy barrier, increases steeply with applied tension in the presence of static tension but is reduced for dichotomically fluctuating tension.
- The mean field wormlike chain model provides a useful analytical model to understand the effect of tension on the looping time.
- The looping time increases exponentially with tension for short chain lengths due to the increasing free energy of loop formation.
- The sensitivity of looping on tension is an emergent behavior that manifests beyond the complexity of real DNA loop formation.
- Recent experiments show that a fluctuating tension on DNA greatly reduces the looping time for small tension values, which may be attributed to an increase in effective temperature.
- Further experiments using dichotomically fluctuating tension with various tension values are needed to establish the resonant activation phenomena in polymer loop formation.
</summary>

• The text discusses a theoretical framework for understanding the inelastic nonlinear mechanical behavior of sticky biopolymer networks using the glassy wormlike chain (GWLC) model.
• The model extends the original equilibrium theory by allowing for a dynamically evolving thermodynamic state variable characterizing the network of thermo-reversible sticky bonds, which is updated upon bond breaking according to an appropriate rate equation.
• The theory predicts a pronounced fluidization response, which develops upon strong deformations on top of the intrinsic viscoelastic stiffening response provided by the individual polymers. After cessation of loading, the system slowly recovers its initial state. The yield force for the onset of fluidization is sensitive to the deformation rate, and the fluidization response is accompanied by a cyclic softening or shake-down effect. Taking into account the spatial heterogeneity of biopolymer solutions by a distribution of entanglement lengths leads to a smoothing of the force-displacement curves without affecting their qualitative characteristics.
</summary>

- Topological insulators (TMI) are a class of materials characterized by non-trivial topological invariants and robust surface metallic states, typically realized in systems with strong spin-orbit interaction and heavy or rare metal elements.
- An extended Hubbard model on the honeycomb lattice has been proposed to generate an effective spin-orbit interaction and realize a TMI phase through spontaneous symmetry breaking at the Hartree-Fock mean-field level.
- However, the stability of this TMI phase against competing orders and quantum fluctuations is not well understood, and reliable examination of stable TMI orders in the extended Hubbard model is hampered by competing symmetry breakings such as charge density waves (CDW).
- The long-period CDW is a major competing order that severely competes with the TMI on the honeycomb lattice, and it is much more stable than the short-period CDW at the mean-field level.
- By reducing the fermi velocity of the dirac cones, the TMI can be stabilized on the honeycomb lattice, and this prescription has been used to realize the TMI in an extended Hubbard model on the honeycomb lattice using a variational Monte Carlo method.
- The TMI emerges in an extended parameter region as a spontaneous symmetry breaking even when many-body and quantum fluctuations are taken into account, by suppressing the fermi velocity to a tenth of that of the original honeycomb lattice.
- The TMI phase is not stabilized when other competing orders, such as CDW and antiferromagnetic states, are taken into account, but it can be stabilized by modulating the fermi velocity at the dirac cones in the electronic band dispersion.
- The TMI phase is expected to have a large single-particle excitation gap, which is crucial for actual applications as a spintronics platform, and theoretical results support that topological insulators with such a large gap can be obtained using abundant carbon atoms.
</summary>

- IME (ime) domain simulation is an important approach for power system dynamic analysis, but the complete system model, or long-term stability model, includes various components with different differential and algebraic equations (DAEs) and time scales.
- The large number of DAEs in a real power system makes time domain simulation over long time intervals expensive and challenging, especially in online stability assessment.
- Two approaches to accelerate long-term stability model simulation are using larger time step sizes or implementing quasi-steady-state (qss) models.
- The qss model suffers from numerical difficulties near singularities and inconsistent approximations of the long-term stability model.
- Pseudo-transient continuation (PTC) method is a theoretical-based numerical method used in power system long-term stability analysis to accelerate simulation speed and overcome possible numerical difficulties in the qss model.
- The long-term stability model for power systems includes algebraic equations and fast and slow ODEs and DDEs that describe the transmission system, internal dynamics of devices, and long-term dynamics such as exponential recovery load, turbine governor, load tap changer, and over excitation limiter.
- The proposed paper applies PTC method to the long-term stability model and qss model in power systems, modifies the original PTC method for its implementation, and presents numerical examples to demonstrate its feasibility and advantages over conventional methods.
</summary>

- A phenomenon called chimera states was discovered in populations of identical phase oscillators under nonlocal symmetric coupling, where coherent (synchronized) and incoherent oscillators coexist @xcite.
- Chimera states have been extensively studied in various models, including Kuramoto phase oscillators, periodic and chaotic maps, and Stuart-Landau oscillators @xcite.
- The first experimental evidence of chimera states was found in populations of coupled chemical oscillators and optical coupled-map lattices @xcite.
- A competition between two antagonistic synchronization patterns in a mechanical experiment involving two subpopulations of identical metronomes led to the emergence of chimera states @xcite.
- In neuroscience, chimera states are believed to explain the phenomenon of unihemispheric sleep observed in many birds and dolphins @xcite.
- This paper aims to identify chimera states in networks of nonlocally coupled neurons represented by Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators for the first time.
- Chimeras were discovered in 2d Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators, where each oscillator interacts with its nearest neighbors through symmetric coupling. A new "mixed oscillatory state" (MOS) was identified, where half of the neurons are attracted to a fixed point and the other half oscillate interspersed among the stationary ones.

</summary>

- Chimeras were also observed in the more realistic 3d Hindmarsh-Rose model, where a third variable representing a slowly varying current was added.
- In this model, chimera states were discovered when coupling was allowed only among the first (membrane potential) variables during spiking within sufficiently long bursting intervals.
- The paper concludes by discussing the importance of studying chimera states in systems modeling neuron dynamics due to their relevance to neuroscience applications and theoretical significance.
- Chimeras and MOS states are currently being investigated in networks of populations of Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators.

• Kauffman networks are disordered dynamical systems proposed by Kauffman in 1969 as a model for genetic regulatory systems.
• They attracted the interest of physicists in the 80s due to their analogy with disordered systems in statistical mechanics.
• A dynamical phase transition was found and studied using mean field theory, and the paper introduces the concept of relevant elements and studies their probability distribution.

• The paper also describes how relevant elements are subdivided into asymptotically non-communicating, independent modules, and shows that the phase transition can be described in terms of the scaling of the number of relevant elements with system size or a percolation transition in the set of relevant elements.
• The approach is interesting because it allows for the derivation of consequences about the statistical properties of the attractors. The paper deals with the magnetization and stable elements in the chaotic phase and on the critical line, and discusses the distribution of relevant elements and its connection with the properties of the attractors.
</summary>

• The Kauffman model is a set of elements with binary variables representing their states of activation, each under the control of other elements and response functions that specify how the element responds to signals from its control variables.
• The control elements are chosen with uniform probability, and the response functions are extracted at random. The dynamics of the system obey a deterministic equation, but the system is disordered due to the random choice of control rules.
• The paper is interested in the statistical properties of systems of large size, such as the probability distributions of the number, length, and size of attraction basins of periodic orbits, as well as transient times.

• The magnetization and stable elements are defined and discussed, with old results and open problems presented. The relevant elements are defined and an approximate argument is given for their scaling with system size in the different phases of the model.

• The text discusses the results of a millimetre and submillimetre survey of 20 low-luminosity active galactic nuclei (LLAGNs) using the Nobeyama Millimetre Array (NMA).
• The study found that at least half of the LLAGNs show inverted spectra between 15 and 96 GHz, which cannot be explained by resolution effects or contamination from dust, free-free, or extended nonthermal emissions.
• The inverted spectra are intrinsic properties of the cores and cannot be caused by the resolution effect.
• The study also found an inverse correlation between the high-frequency radio spectrum and the low-frequency radio core power, which can be explained by different flux ratios between the jet and the accretion disc in different LLAGNs.
• The findings provide evidence for the existence of the advection-dominated accretion flow (ADAF) in LLAGNs and encourage further studies at higher frequency ranges to prove the ADAF model.
